results.title: In the heat of the night
results.creator_credit: Mirisch Corporation, Walter Mirisch and Norman Jewison
results.brief_description: Set in the deep South at the height of the early 60’s racial tension, this superbly crafted murder mystery deserved all five of its Academy Awards. Best actor winner Rod Steiger gives a definitive performance as a small town, red-neck sheriff who finds himself in an uneasy alliance with a black homicide detective from Philadelphia, strikingly portrayed by Sidney Poitier. In the course of investigating the crime, the two strong-willed men must reconcile their inherent prejudice towards each other. The final result is justice and an unlikely but touching mutual respect. Supporting performances by Warren Oates and Lee Grant, an evocative score by Quincy Jones and Haskell Wexler’s vivid cinematography combine to create the stifling aura of a hot summer evening in the South. The Oscar winning script by Stirling Silliphant is based on a novel by John Ball.

results.title: In search of Anna
results.creator_credit: Storm Productions, Australian Film Commission, Victorian Film Corporation and Esben Storm
results.brief_description: Tony has just been released from Pentridge after serving six years for robbery. He sets out to settle old scores and search for his girlfriend Anna. In the process he hitches a ride north with the enigmatic Sam and a relationship develops between them. The theme of coming to terms with the past is expressed formally through the non-chronological structure which produces a split narrative - the Melbourne scenes and the journey north - which inform each other as the story unfolds. Underlying the journey to awareness is the city/country antinomy - the country has the power to liberate what the city has entrapped. Features the music of AC/DC, Rose Tattoo, Stiletto, The Angels and Steve Wright. Cast includes Richard Moir, Judy Morris, Chris Haywood, Bill Hunter, Ian Nimmo, Maurie Fields.

results.title: In our water
results.brief_description: South Brunswick, New Jersey; Spring, 1975. Frank Kaler and his family are convinced there is something wrong with their water; vegetables cooked in it change colour, skin lesions appear after bathing in it. The health department claims that it is drinkable, but it is later determined to be some of the most toxic drinking water in the country.

results.title: In God's hands
results.creator_credit: Tri-Star Pictures, Tom Stern and Zalman King
results.brief_description: In God’s Hands follows three friends and surfers around the world in their quest for the perfect wave. They travel to Madagascar, Mexico, Bali and Hawaii where their training is put to the test when faced with 40 foot waves travelling at 35 miles per hour. Includes stunning water photography by Sonny Miller. Cast includes: Patrick Shane Dorian, Matt George, Matty Liu and Shaun Tomson.

results.title: In country
results.creator_credit: Warner Bros Pictures, Norman Jewison and Richard Roth
results.brief_description: At seventeen, Samantha Hughes of Hopewell, Kentucky is pretty, energetic, headstrong and curious; curious about the father she never knew, and curious about the war that took him away - the war nobody wants to remember. Bruce Willis plays a reclusive vet in this story of a family’s struggle to heal the wounds of Vietnam. This film captures both the horror of battle and the disillusionment of a young soldier who thought war meant glory. Norman Jewison directs this heartfelt and powerful movie highlighted by one of the most poignant final scenes ever filmed - the family’s emotionally stirring, almost wordless visit to the Vietnam Veteran’s Memorial in Washington D.C. “In country” is the term American GI’s used for their time in Vietnam. Based on the novel by Bobbie Ann Mason.

results.title: In bed with Madonna = Truth or dare
results.creator_credit: Propaganda Films, Boy Toy Inc, Tim Clawson, Jay Roewe and Alek Keshishian
results.brief_description: Insightful documentary revolving around the singer Madonna on her Blonde Ambition tour, which remarks upon the nature of fame and celebrity culture. Keshishian follows Madonna on tour presenting her magnificently staged live shows (in colour) and her backstage and after hours shenanigans (in black and white). Madonna is depicted as a consummate performer dedicated to her art but whose identity and personhood are inextricably complicated by her infamy and the contemporary superstar obsession. Voice-over from Madonna provides insight into her perspective on fame, family, and creative expression. Interviews include Madonna’s brother, and her numerous dancers, some of whom discuss their ambitions and insecurities. When the camera turns to Warren Beatty (Madonna’s then boyfriend), he proves to be a prickly subject and questions the nature of the honesty of the documentary being made. This work was indeed criticised for it sanitation and artificiality due to the fact that the content was tightly controlled by Madonna. Despite that assertion, Keshishian’s lingering takes provide remarkable material that should prove appealing to those with an interest in contemporary culture, and extremely entertaining to music fans. The film also touches on issues of sexuality, Queer pride, artistic integrity and censorship.

results.title: In America
results.creator_credit: Fox Searchlight, Hell's Kitchen, Jim Sheridan and Arthur Lappin
results.brief_description: From the director of “My Left Foot” and “In the name of the Father” comes a moving portrait of an Irish immigrant family trying to establish a new life in the US after a devastating tragedy. The father (Paddy Considine) is a struggling actor who ends up driving a taxi at night to make a living while the mother (Samantha Morton) raises their two adorable girls (played by real life sisters Sarah and Emma Bolger) while working at a nearby ice-cream parlour. The eldest of the two girls uses her home video camera as a way to document their current life and deal with the past - much of the strength and delight of the film comes from the roles of the children. Set in New York City in a dilapidated apartment building they share with drug dealers, pimps and other poor families, the girls be-friend a neighbour Mateo (Djimon Hounsou) who provides the family with a new outlook and helps them face their grief, while he deals with his own mortality. The loosely autobiographical script is based on Jim Sheridan’s life and was co-written with his two daughters Naomi and Kirsten Sherdian. Nominated for three Academy Awards in 2003.

results.title: In a lonely place
results.creator_credit: Santana, Robert Lord and Nicholas Ray
results.brief_description: Dixon Steele (Humphrey Bogart), a neurotic and deeply disturbed screenwriter on the down-hill slide is accused of murdering the hatcheck girl of his favourite hang-out. To his surprise, he is supplied with an alibi by his next door neighbour, Laurel Gray (Gloria Grahame). Brub Nicholai (Frank Lovejoy), the investigating officer and a former war buddy of Dix, remains unconvinced and exerts pressure on his friend in order to make him crack. Meanwhile, Dixon and Laurel embark on a romance, but the extreme pressure Dixon must endure both from the police and the studios, soon brings out his violent temper. As the romance disintegrates, so too does Dixon’s mental state. During filming Gloria Grahame’s relationship with director Nicholas Ray ended, and many saw in Bogart’s character a reflection of Ray’s own personal turmoils. Bogart himself drew away from the immaculate persona so often used in his previous films to create a flawed and hounded human being. Critical of Hollywood mores (although it was scripted by Andrew Solt, a recent emigre screenwriter who was absolutely charmed by it), the film bears none of the strange fascination for the studio setting contained in an other Hollywood insiders film made the same year: ‘Sunset Boulevard’. Adapted from the novel ‘In a Lonely Place’ by Dorothy B. Hughes. Reference: Bernard Eisenschitz. ‘Nicholas Ray: an American Journey’ Faber and Faber, 1990.

results.title: Immortal beloved [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: ICON, Bruce Davey and Bernard Rose
results.brief_description: When a cryptic letter from musical genius, Beethoven, turned up shortly after his death, it started one of history’s most compelling romantic mysteries. An enduring riddle that remains unsolved to this day. Who, among the scores of women that Beethoven seduced, was his “Immortal Beloved”? Gary Oldman and Isabella Rossellini share a love as hypnotic as the music Beethoven created, in this enthralling film based on the celebrated life of one of the greatest composers that ever lived.
